widespread.  The  main  component  of  the  project  will  facilitate  more  regional  trade  and  higher

A. 

Rationale 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

3.  
The Kyrgyz Republic plays a crucial role in regional trade and transit traffic because its 
roads form part of the transport network in Central Asia. The condition of the Kyrgyz Republic’s 
road network and its management improved substantially from 2005 to 2010. However, several 
dilapidated network links and poor infrastructure management skills continue to hamper regional 
trade  and  economic  growth. 2  The  project  will  help  the  government  make  some  of  these 
improvements  in  accordance  with  Strategy  2020  and  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).3 
The project fits within ADB’s Country Partnership Strategy for the Kyrgyz Republic.4 

4.  
Aside  from  being  landlocked,  80%  of  the  Kyrgyz  Republic’s  land  is  covered  by  the 
Tian Shan  mountain range.  Trade  and  travel  are  almost  entirely  dependent  on  road  transport. 
More  than  90%  of  the  passenger  trips  and  about  60%  of  the  freight  in  2009  was  moved  by 
road.5 This  has  been  made  partly  possible  by  development  partner  assistance  since  1996  to 
upgrade about 2,000 kilometers (km) of strategic roads. More roads are waiting to be improved. 
The 539 km Bishkek–Torugart road is one of them. Its surface, most bridges, and safety devices 
are  either  inadequate  or  functionally  obsolete.  Traffic  volumes  in  several  sections  exceed  the 
capacities, causing heavy delays during the summer months, and movement in some sections 
is frequently interrupted by landslides, snow drifts, waterlogging, and flooding. 

The  Bishkek–Torugart  road  plays  several  important  functions.  It  is  part  of  the  CAREC 
5.  
Corridor 1(c), which extends from Troitsk in the Russian Federation to Kashi in Xinjiang Uygur 
Autonomous  Region  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC);  it  is  the  shortest  thoroughfare 
from  Bishkek  to  Kashi;  and  the  only  north–south  trunk  road  in  the  central  Kyrgyz  Republic, 
connecting Naryn oblast (province), the poorest of the Kyrgyz Republic’s seven oblasts, and the 
city  of  Naryn  to the  rest  of  the  country.6 It  is  also  the  only  road  that  provides  direct  access  at 
present to Issyk Kul lake region, one of Central Asia’s best known tourist destinations with huge 
potential  to  grow.  However,  the  costly,  slow,  unreliable,  and  unsafe  travel  caused  by  the  poor 
road condition  has  hampered the  development of the  entire corridor,  particularly  Naryn  oblast. 
Imports from the PRC continue to grow, but exports are limited to a few products because only

6.  
Although  the  government  prepared  the  Road  Sector  Development  Strategy  for  2007–
2010, in which the Bishkek–Torugart road improvement features prominently as an action item, 
it  lacked  resources  for  implementing  the  strategy.7 As  the  country’s  first  development  partner 
and  largest  multilateral  lender  to  the  road  sector,  ADB  was  first  to  offer  to  meet  part  of  the 
resource need. In 2008 and 2009, it financed the improvement of 114 km (km 365–km 479) of 
this  road.8 It  is  also  helping  the  government  through  CAREC  to  strengthen  trade  ties  with  its 
neighbors. The government of the PRC provided $200 million in 2010 to improve 223 km (from 
km  9  to  km  272).9 Works  under  these  projects  are  progressing  mostly  on  schedule,  and  are 
expected  to  be  completed  by  the  end  of  2014.  The  government  is  discussing  with  the  Arab 
Coordination Group a financing package of $80 million for improving 93 km (km 272–km 365).10 
If unimproved, the 60 km section from km 479 to km 539 at the Kyrgyz  Republic–PRC border 
will be the only bottleneck in the corridor. 

Infrastructure  preservation  is  another  task  that  the  government  has  yet  to  accomplish 
7.  
efficiently. Between 1996 and 2010, total investment in road improvement exceeded $1 billion—
ADB  provided  about  $300  million  of  this.  However,  investment  in  preservation  was  about  $28 
million  in  2009,  six  times  more  than  in  2005;  only  half  of  what  was  needed  to  keep  the 
19,000 km  network  under  the  jurisdiction  of  the  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Communications 
(MOTC)  in  good  shape.  Cost  recovery  from  road  users  covers  only  a fraction  of  the  needs  at 
present,  and  the  government  is  facing  ever-rising  construction  and  maintenance  costs. 
Therefore, more attention must be paid to preservation. For this, the government not only needs 
tools—legislation,  policies,  techniques,  and  procedures—but  also  skilled  staff  to  use  the  tool 
and to champion change. 

8.  
The project will help the government improve the 60 km section from At Beit to Torugart 
at  the  PRC  border, the  last  segment  of the  Bishkek–Torugart  road. Together  with the  ongoing 
improvement  works  in the other  sections,  it  will  enable all-weather road  travel  from  Bishkek to 
Kashi.  Aside  from  the  economic  benefits  of  higher  speeds  and  reliability,  the  better  road 
geometry  and  protective  structures  resulting  from  the  improvement  will  reduce  the  accidental 
toxic spill risk and material runoff from vehicles. These reductions will benefit the ecosystem of 
Chatyr  Kul  Lake—a  wetland  of  international  significance  that  is  protected  under  the  Ramsar 
Convention on Wetlands.

 The project will also strengthen the infrastructure management skills of government staff 
9.  
engaged  in  the  road  sector.  This  is  an  essential  and  natural  complement  to  the  capital 
investment.  ADB  provided  technical  assistance  for  institutional  strengthening  and  capacity 
building totaling nearly $6 million from 1996 to 2010. The World Bank and the European Bank 
for Reconstruction and Development have further assistance programmed for 2011. These are 
short  and one-off  interventions. The  project,  in contrast,  supports  a long-term, results-oriented 
program of learning and development for government staff. It will result in better informed staff, 
equipped to champion strategies for reducing lifecycle costs and improving user cost recovery.11 

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

10.  
The  project’s  impact  will  be  increased  regional  trade,  particularly  between  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic and the PRC. Its outcome will be higher mobility for people and goods with origins and 
destinations  in the road corridor  between Naryn  and Torugart.12 The  project  complements  and 
utilizes the synergy created by road sector investments by other development partners.13 

C. 

Outputs 

11.  
The project’s primary output will be 60 km of two-lane Bishkek–Torugart road (km 479–
km  539)  repaired,  rehabilitated,  or  reconstructed  to  national  Category  III  road  standards  with 
special  structures  for  protecting  the  environment,  preserving  the  road  structure,  and  reducing 
vehicle crashes. This will be delivered through the civil works component. The other output will 
be  improved  infrastructure  management  skills  of  MOTC  and  other  government  agency  staff. 
This will be achieved through training, education, and mentoring from national and international 
consultants.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

14.   MOTC  will  be  the  executing  agency.  It  has  implemented  all  development  partner 
financed  road  projects  since  1995,  and  has  accumulated  considerable  experience.  The 
investment  project  implementation  group  (IPIG)  in  MOTC  will  be  responsible  for  day-to-day 
administration  of  project  activities. The IPIG  was established  in 1996,  and  has  since  delivered 
more than 12 road projects valued at nearly $500 million. The IPIG has 29 full-time staff, and is 
implementing  13 projects  with  an  estimated  total  value  of  $520  million.  Its  project  delivery 
performance  in  terms  of  timeliness  and  final  cost  to  date  has  been  satisfactory,  and  staff  has 
adequate  technical  know-how  and  understanding  of  ADB  procedures  to  manage  the  project. 
There are provisions in the project to enhance delivery performance in terms of timeliness and 
budget  adherence.  MOTC  will  engage  consultants,  financed  from  the  loan,  as  and  when 
needed,  to  assist  its  staff  with  complex  issues,  especially  those  related  to  environmental 
management and ecosystem preservation. It will also engage consultants to improve staff skills 
on project delivery. 

15.   MOTC  will  procure  civil  works  and  consulting  services  for  civil  works  supervision  from 
firms  with  global  experience  and  proven  records  of  efficient  delivery.  The  implementation 
arrangements  are  summarized  in  Table  3  and  described  in  detail  in  the  project  administration 
manual (PAM).14

Technical 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

16.   MOTC has prepared detailed design drawings, specifications, and bills of quantities for 
the  civil  works. These  would normally  be  adequate for  an  admeasurement  contract (based  on 
bills  of  quantities).  However,  the  project  site  conditions  are  unique.  Its  elevation  is  more  than 
3,000  meters,  the  ground  there  is  permanently  frozen,  and  the  road  alignment  is  close  to  a 
unique  wetland.  Therefore,  the  current  design  will  require  numerous  changes  during 
construction.  Accordingly,  MOTC  will  procure  the  civil  works  using  the  design-build  project 
delivery method according to specifications detailed in ADB’s standard bidding documents. This 
method  allows  (i)  MOTC  to  share  the  cost,  delay,  and  the  risk  of  design  changes  with  the 
contractor; and (ii) the contractor to use technology and construction methods more economical 
and relevant to the site. Past data suggests that the initial price of design-build contracts is 5%–
10% higher than admeasurement method contracts, but the final price of design-build contracts 
is often less. Moreover, under a design-build contract, MOTC and the construction supervision 
consultant can focus more on output quality, which is critical at this site.

B. 

Economic and Financial 

17.  
The  benefit  of  the  project  is  dependent  on  the  improvement  of  the  entire  Bishkek–
Torugart road,  which provides  both  national  and  international  access  to the  people  and goods 
within  and  outside  the  corridor.  Improvement  of  the  entire  Bishkek–Torugart  road  will  bring 
about  significant  regional  benefits,  because  it  helps  increase  trade,  particularly  between  the 
Kyrgyz  Republic  and  the  PRC.  MOTC  and  ADB  have  found  the  economic  benefits  of  the 
investment in the road to be robust and sustainable. The economic internal rate of return on the 
investment is about 34%, assuming that all other sections of the road are improved by the end 
of 2015.15  

18.  
The government recognizes that the increasing number of heavy vehicles and their axle 
loads  are  reducing  the  service  life  of  many  roads,  and  that  this  trend  has  to  be  reversed  for 
preserving the newly created assets. Besides continuing to increase the maintenance budget, it 
is implementing axle load limits on roads according to the design standards. However, if loads 
exceed the limit, under the present scheme, the vehicles are charged a fee and allowed on the 
road.  The  government  will,  therefore,  revise  the  fees  and  tolls  to  reflect  the  level  of  use  and 
vehicle type, and ban vehicles with axle loads in excess of limit. 

C. 

Governance 

19.   MOTC  has  been  following  ADB’s  safeguards,  procurement  and  financial  management 
guidelines, policies, and procedures for implementing road projects since 1996, and its staff  is 
knowledgeable  about  ADB’s  requirements.  Project  accounts  will  be  audited  annually  by  a 
private  audit  firm  acceptable  to  ADB.  Past  audit  reports  on  ADB  projects  have  not  highlighted 
any  irregularities.  MOTC  will  conduct  periodic  technical  audits  of  the  work  of  the  supervision 
consultant  and  contractor  as  part  of  its  increased  oversight  of  works,  services,  and  goods 
contracts. MOTC will also train its staff under the skills development component of the project, 
and introduce internal financial audits and technical audits.16

D. 

Poverty and Social 

21.   When  viewed  in  the  context  of  the  entire  Bishkek–Torugart  road,  the  project  will  bring 
significant benefits to both the people of Naryn oblast and the Kyrgyz Republic as a whole, and 
will also have positive impacts on poverty reduction in the PRC. The 30% reduction in trip times 
and  vehicle  operating  costs  from  Torugart  to  Naryn  will  increase  activity  at  the  freight  transit 
center  in  Naryn  city.  This  will  create  more  jobs  and  increase  the  demand  for  local  services.17 
People residing along the road will be able to find employment in physical works and ancillary 
services during construction. The increase in traffic will help sustain the service businesses that 
people  started  during  construction.  Civil  works  and  service  contracts  financed  by  ADB  will 
require equal employment opportunities, wages, and relevant working conditions to be given to 
women. The government  has gradually  increased  border  and  internal  security  monitoring,  and

E. 

Safeguards 

22.  
The project is classified as environmental category A, because about 35 km of the road 
passes in close  proximity  to  Chatyr  Kul  Lake  protected  area.  ADB  assisted the government  in 
conducting an environmental impact assessment (EIA), which shows that (i) the impacts during 
construction  are  mostly  acute,  temporary,  and  reversible,  with  the  exception  of  possible 
hazardous  materials  spills;  (ii)  potential  impacts  during  operations  are  expected  to  be  much 
greater  as the road  has a  design  lifetime  of  20+ years,  and pollutants  entering the  Chatyr  Kul 
aquatic ecosystem could accumulate because the lake has no outlet; (iii) some improvements in 
dust, noise, and vibration are expected; and (iv) long-term impacts caused by increased traffic, 
vehicle emissions, and possible hazardous materials spills pose potential risks to the Chatyr Kul 
ecosystem. 

23.  
The draft EIA report was discussed with the stakeholders and disclosed to the public in 
November  2010.18 The report  contains  a two-track  environmental management  plan  (EMP) for 
(i) pollutant source control, and (ii) receptor (biodiversity) protection. The control and protection 
measures  include  speed  limits,  signs,  and  special  permits  for  hazardous  material  movement, 
and  hydraulic  structures  such  as  retention  pods  and  diversion  channels  to  prevent  runoff 
pollutants and accidentally spilled toxic substances from entering the wetlands.

resources,  with an  interest  charge  at the  rate  of  1.0%  per  annum  during the grace  period  and

other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft
